item.title: Comment on A funny feature of the AI doomster argument by Hadur
item.description:
Reply to Hadur:

I'm not an AI doomer, but I also have little respect for Tyler's frequent use of "but are you investing that way?" as a retort to anyone he disagrees with. It is possible to have legitimate insight but also neither the inclination nor the ability to change your investment strategies to match it.

For a short bet specifically, there's also the critical difference that timing is critical. The CEO of Coca-Cola predicted the Great Depression and lost his shirt from shorting the market in 1928 when he thought it would start. The author of my college Corporate Finance textbook predicted that Internet Explorer would beat out Netscape and lost six figures shorting Netscape too early.

If you predicted a specific apocalypse in 5 years and that specific apocalypse happens in 10 years, most would say that is a pretty good prediction. But as investing advice it would end with you and anyone who listened to you going bankrupt and then entering the apocalypse with abysmal credit scores.

item.title: Comment on A funny feature of the AI doomster argument by Ben Smith
item.description:
No apparent signs up to the last minute is more plausible than you think.

Doomers also said in the 2010s the world was underprepared for a pandemic. Then a pandemic happened! It happened very quickly and there was no noticeable market moment until the last minute, say, weeks *after* Covid-19 had arrived in the USA.
